subtitle: The inaugural issue of the New Thinking Allowed
magazine was just released on March 1st.
You can download a free PDF copy from the New Thinking Allowed Foundation website.
That's newthinkingallowed.org.
You can even order a printed copy from nta-magazine.magcloud.com.
Thinking Allowed, conversations on the
leading edge of knowledge and discovery with
psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome.
I'm Jeffrey Mishlove.
Today, we'll be exploring meditation.
With me is Stephen Schwartz, who has been a daily meditator for many decades.
He is the author of many books, including The Secret Vaults of Time, The Alexandria
Project, The Eight Laws of Change, How to Become
an Agent for Personal and Social Transformation,
and Opening to the Infinite.
Stephen is a parapsychology researcher, an
anthropological researcher, and an interdisciplinary
scholar.
Welcome, Stephen.
Pleasure.
Pleasure to be with you.
Our discussion on meditation was inspired, really, by an earlier conversation we had
that meditators are better remote viewers.
That's one of many reasons to meditate.
It's one of many.
Yes.
What I say to people, I believe it, I look at it in my own life, is the greatest gift
you can give yourself is to develop the daily practice of meditation.
I can think of nothing else, man or woman, that you can do to improve your life than
to develop the daily practice of meditation.
Twenty minutes a day will change your life in ways that you can hardly imagine.
And if you look at the research literature, the last time I looked, there was something
in PubMed, the National Medical Library.
There were something like 1,300 physiological
papers, just changes in your body.
Meditators, 20 minutes of meditation a day will reduce the thinning of the prefrontal
cortex and the brain stem that occur in aging,
so it has a positive effect on your ability
to hold your mental abilities as you age.
It will give you better resistance, it improves
your immune system, it increases your ability
to concentrate, your sleep will be better,
your general health will improve, you'll have
a better sex life.
I mean, it just goes on and on and on and on.
And more than that, it has huge social implications.
Four incidents in San Francisco, the four worst schools in San Francisco.
By worst, I mean highest dropout rate, most
violence, everything you would think by worst.
These are kids who grow up in violent, low-income,
conflicted circumstances, and they were having
a lot of trouble in the schools, and they
instituted a 20-minute-a-day meditation program.
And not a religious program, and I think it's
very important from the beginning that we
separate.
We can say many religions teach about meditation,
but you can do meditation with no religious
context at all.
In any case, I mean, much of it today in medicine, we call it mindfulness.
Yes.
Or, I believe, Benson Herbert wrote a book
many years ago called The Relaxation Response.
Yes, Herbert Benson.
Herbert Benson.
Yeah, Harvard.
And I confuse them because there's a Benson
Herbert who was a researcher in parapsychology.
That's right.
But in any case, so they taught these kids a simple mindfulness meditation technique,
20 minutes a day.
And the students, they thought, well, they'd
never sit still for it, that they would be
too antsy, and no.
In fact, as it went along, the students embraced
it, and a couple of times when they didn't
do it because something else was on, the students complained.
But the net effect was that dropouts decreased
enormously, graduation rates increased, school
violence decreased, violence with these children,
even in their neighborhoods, decreased, their
lives generally improved, their study habits improved, their grades went up.
And this was teaching them 20 minutes of a
relaxation mindfulness meditation technique.
So this has not only individual implications,
but it has really significant objectively
measurable, this is not conjecture or speculation, social outcome measurements.
It's easy to learn.
The research suggests really that it's much
less important which technique you use because
all of them are essentially ritual behavior.
What matters is that you develop the ability to
attain and sustain intention-focused awareness.
I mean, in the parapsychological world, we see that meditators do better at non-local
perception tasks than non-meditators, but much more importantly, I think, because not
everybody wants to be a remote viewer, is that
meditation in addition to its physiological
benefits which are many, changes your whole psychology of your life.
The whole way you look at the world, the way
you interact with people, it has an effect
on your relationships.
The key is not to become involved with a kind
of sectarianism where you think this way of
meditating is the only way.
Because the research, as I say, suggests that
what really matters is that you have this
daily practice where you are basically allowing
the cognitive activity of your mind to calm
and you allow yourself to relax.
Now, your blood pressure goes down, your stress
levels go down, all these physical things
I was mentioning are happening, but also your capacity to cope with stress goes up.
There just isn't anything else that I know of that an individual can do, independent
of money, social position, race, educational
level, any of these external definers.
There is just nothing else that you can do that will improve your life than developing
the daily practice of meditation.
Now, I do know a few people who have negative experiences meditating.
One person, for instance, tells me when they
try to meditate they have dark thoughts.
Oh, yes.
Well, in the transcendental meditation culture
they use the phrase unstressing, that when
you meditate you let go of stress and in the
process of letting go it's stressful itself
from time to time.
Yes, that's my problem with a lot of the various
schools of meditation are, A, they tell you
this is the only way to do it or the best way
and, two, they get caught up in the ritual
behavior and they believe that the ritual behavior is the key, not just a part of the
process.
And so being non-stressed is very stressful.
My approach to meditation, which is developed
out of the research, not out of any religious
orientation, is basically to develop this
technique for attaining and sustaining intention
focused awareness and I have, well, perhaps it's worth saying it, it's very simple and
this is the way I teach it and I've taught thousands of people to do this.
First of all, start with the place.
You want to pick your place where you're going to do it.
Now at one level that's just a way of reinforcing
but as we have discussed in other interviews
there is also something that happens to the information architecture of the space.
You create a sacred space for yourself.
You create a sacred space, exactly.
So you pick your place.
You pick your time.
I happen to meditate at night.
Other people like to do it early in the morning.
The truth is it doesn't matter.
It's that you are consistent.
So pick your place, pick your space.
Next thing, pick your central phrase and your
central phrase could be a mantra and there
are reasons for using mantras because the reiteration of sound sequences produces a
numinous effect, a numinosity effect because
people have been doing it for thousands of
years or whatever.
So you pick your central phrase but it could
also be a poem, a line out of a poem, a line
out of a song.
It could be a bumper sticker.
It doesn't matter.
What you want is something that expresses your sense of yourself where you are and at
the same time your aspiration for where you would like to be.
So you might start with be still and know that all is one.
I just made that up.
Not bad.
But the point being that I feel disconnected.
I feel lonely.
I feel cut off.
I don't feel like I'm appreciated.
All of those kinds of things.
And you wanted to have meaning as opposed to say a mantra like om.
Yes.
Yes.
Because it's not that, as I say, mantras are
very good but the thing is that we associate
meditation with the East.
Now in fact there have been techniques of
meditation in every culture of humanity forever.
And when other people were saying mantras,
for instance, in another language, many other
people understood the language.
So it was be still and know that all is one.
I don't know what that would be if you translated
it into Urdu or something but just because
a mantra comes from another culture doesn't mean that that's the optimal thing for you
to do.
You prefer people to understand what they're doing.
And so you pick a central phrase and we'll in this instance say be still and know that
all is one.
Then you pick four words or small phrases, just a couple of words, a single word or a
multiple words, a physical word, an emotional
word, a mental word, and a spiritual word.
So you have four words.
And just for the illustration, let's say that
you have a chronic problem with overeating.
And so your conception of yourself and your present situation is I eat too much.
When I get stressed, I compulsively eat as an example.
And so what I aspire to is that I will use food correctly.
So your physical word might be food.
You have a mental word.
And I make a difference between a mental and
emotional word because I have learned over
the years that if you say to people, well, what do you think about that?
They'll say, well, I feel.
Or if you say, well, how do you feel about that?
Well, I think.
So mental-emotional separation.
So let's say that your mental word is concentration.
I feel like my mind is a flippity-jibbit.
I just can't seem to stay focused on anything.
What I really want to be able to do is to think something through clearly and really
stay focused on it.
And so let's say that your word would be focus.
Your emotional word might be I would like to feel that I am recognized and people see
me for who I am and that they see me clearly.
And I would like to not always be constantly
driven by the emotions that upset me.
I'd like to have clarity.
And so this emotional word would be clarity.
And then for your spiritual word, you might,
for instance, say, well, you know, I went
to church when I was a child, but I never really had any sense that I was a part of
any greater thing or that there was any sort of oneness or anything like that.
And so I would, you know, what I really long for is to feel a sense of connection.
And so your word might be connection, all right?
So now you have four.
You have your central phrase, your physical
word, your mental word, your emotional word,
your spiritual word.
Okay.
So five items.
Five items.
You have your place.
You have your time.
Now, what you're going to discover when you
do this is that this place that you've picked
because it's very quiet, that suddenly it'll become very crowded.
And the time that you pick that you thought,
well, I can do it this time, that it'll suddenly
become complicated because the robotic behaviors
that the unconscious robotic patterns of behavior,
they don't want to be reclaimed and they fight back.
And so...
Which is why people get restless sometimes when they meditate.
Exactly.
And why they...
Suddenly I'm filled with dark thoughts.
So there you are.
You have your place.
You have your time.
You have your central phrase.
You have your words.
You're sitting.
You can sit.
Don't lie down because you'll fall asleep because most people don't get enough sleep.
And whenever they actually stop, they tend to fall asleep.
So it's better to be seated.
And you don't have to sit in a particular posture.
If you like a particular posture, sit that way.
And there are subtle nuances that suggest that certain postures or hand mudras, hand
configurations.
But that's all...
That's like saying, you know, I'm Michael
Jordan and I'm worried about whether my hands
are holding the ball.
I mean, when you get to that level of subtlety, you deal with that.
We just keep it very straightforward.
So you sit there.
You sit for...
You're 20 minutes.
You say your phrase.
You want to be erect the way you are.
Erect.
Sit in a chair, comfortable.
Otherwise...
Your spine is straight.
Yes.
Your spine is straight.
You're sitting comfortably in a chair.
Your feet are on the floor.
You're in a comfortable position.
And you sit there.
You close your eyes.
You take a deep breath.
You let it out.
You take a deep breath.
You let it out.
You take a deep breath.
You let it out.
And as you do that, you feel your mind calming.
It's like a still pool in the forest.
And you say your phrase, be still and know that all is one.
You say it again, be still and know that all is one.
You say it a third time, be still and know that all is one.
And then you stop.
And for a while, there will be nothing.
But after a little while, for most Westerners
particularly, and this is a meditation for
modern minds, after a little while, thoughts will begin to bubble up.
When they bubble up, if they relate to your central phrase, you think them.
If they don't relate to your central phrase,
you stop, you take a deep breath, and you
say your phrase again once or twice.
And then you stop.
There will be nothing.
After a while, things will bubble up.
If they relate to the phrase, you stop and you think them.
When they begin to wonder, oh, I'm going to have to go to that dinner party and blah,
blah, blah, you stop, you say it again.
You do that through the course.
Now, what will happen over time is that some
days you'll have to do that a number of times,
and other days you may only have to do it once or twice.
And at the end of your meditation, closing of the 20 minutes, you picture yourself and
you say first your physical phrase, food.
And you feel, you don't think, you just feel
both your recognition of where you are and
your aspirational concept of yourself, I'm going to be in control of my food, food.
You just say that, food.
You can picture it arcing out if you want, and then your next word, and then your next
word, and your next word.
Now, what will happen over time is that a
word will go flat, and you'll understand what
that means.
You'll lose its emotional attachment, its numinous quality.
And when you look at your life, you'll suddenly
realize, oh, my goodness, I'm no longer eating
compulsively.
You haven't struggled with it.
You cannot wrestle with the robots.
In other words, you mean after a period of time of weeks of meditating.
Oh, it could be weeks, months, it could be years.
But not minutes during the meditation.
No, no, no, no.
Do your meditation every day, your central
phrase in your physical, your mental, emotional,
spiritual words.
No, after a period of time, the word will go flat, however long that takes is however
long it takes.
But what will happen is when you look at your
life, you will realize without even struggling
or without even consciously intending to do it,
that your whole habit patterns have changed.
You know, there's whole schools of psychology about wrestling with the robots.
Well, that's not the way to do it.
The way to do it is simply to dissolve the robots, as it were, by holding a different
intention.
And when that happens, then you come up with a new word.
Now, they won't necessarily go physical, mental, emotional, spiritual.
Maybe the mental word will go flat first.
And then you'll realize, oh, my goodness, I'm able to focus.
I'm thinking much more clearly.
It just kind of happened.
And over time, even your central phrase will go flat.
Now, I will tell you, I've been a daily meditator
since 1964, so half a century, basically.
And my central phrase, I developed this technique
about five or six years into meditating when
I began doing a lot of research on it.
My central phrase has gone flat four times in 50 years.
My individual power words, I've changed a number of them.
I mean, I have changed my entire life, in fact.
My entire life has changed from who I was pre-meditating to who I am today.
And most of it has occurred without any particular conscious attention to it.
I eat differently, I focus, I'm able to accomplish
things, you know, I get a lot of stuff done.
You do.
So for people who say they don't have time to meditate, you're a great example of how
somehow taking the time to meditate creates more time.
Absolutely.
You know, I've published something like 150 papers, I've written five books, I do the
Daily Schwartz Report, I write my column, I write stuff for things like the Huffington
Post or Smithsonian.
You're out on the speaking circuit.
I speak, all kinds of things.
You make movies?
I make movies, I just wrote a novel.
And a screenplay.
And a screenplay.
The point being, it's not, I'm not doing anything that anybody can't do.
The point that I want to leave you with is that this simple technique of these words
of power and your central phrase and this
simple little process of sitting for 20 minutes
a day will literally alter your life in a life-affirming, compassionate way that you
can hardly imagine.
And I just don't know anything else that will do that.
Well, you've really been added in a disciplined way.
I can say for myself, I am happy with the way things have worked out, but I would be
what I call an undisciplined meditator.
I meditate when and where I feel like it.
Well, and you'll get to that.
But the problem is you have to convince yourself you're serious.
The process of meditation is a process of self-exploration.
And so, just for starters, the reason you pick the place, I mean, I meditate all over
the place, but the reason you start with the
place and the time, and I also, although I
meditate at night because my wife and I meditate
and then she goes to bed and I go back to
work.
But the point for doing that initially is you have to convince yourself that you're
not BSing yourself because you've had lots of things, not you, but we all do, oh, I'm
going to make this commitment.
I'm going to make my New Year's resolution,
but I'm not going to take it real seriously.
So first of all, you have to convince yourself
that you're serious about what you're doing.
And if you will do this, as I say, the benefits
that arise from this are so extraordinary.
Well, I don't hold myself up as a role model.
I can say that.
Well, no, no, but you are a regular meditator
and I'm sure you would say it's made a big
difference in your life.
Absolutely.
I totally subscribe to everything you've said about meditation and its benefits.
Yeah, I mean, and it doesn't have to be done,
it doesn't have to be a religious context.
There is no one way to meditate.
There's no magic bullet about it.
People get hung up in the ritual behavior.
We've talked about remote viewing in these interviews and there are people that this
is the only way to remote view.
There are cults.
Yeah, that's a cult.
That's right.
But the truth is, it's all ritual behavior
to allow you to open to the non-local aspect
of your consciousness.
Well, one of the interesting things, and I think you're familiar with this too, is the
One Meditation Organization claims that the
more people who meditate, the better all sorts
of social indicators in the environment improve.
Yes, I actually tried to do a study on that.
You know, there was a group, maybe we shouldn't
name them, but they claim that if you've got
a group of meditators, you could lower the crime rate, and they published a couple of
papers on it.
Many papers.
Yeah.
Dozens.
Yeah.
So I thought, well, that really, gosh, that'd be great.
So I went down, a friend of mine was a deputy
chief of police in Los Angeles, and I got
the Los Angeles Police Department to go along with
it, and they happened to have an extraordinarily
sophisticated data collection system and database.
So they can tell you at 3 o'clock in the morning
at 3842 Walnut Street, the probability that
a crime will occur.
I mean, it's really amazingly sophisticated.
So I went down to talk to them, and a guy named Marty Reiser, who in those days was
the head of this biometric department.
I know who he is.
Yeah.
And he said, well, just for starters, Stephen,
do you know about the Kansas window study?
No.
He said, well, we know that if you break a window in a building in a neighborhood and
nobody repairs it after three weeks, crime will go up.
Or he said, there's the black and white study.
I said, what's that?
He said, well, if one more black and white
patrol car goes through a neighborhood, crime
will go down.
And as I got further and further into this with him, I realized that when you try to
do a study like that really rigorously, that
there are simply so many variables you can't
control that you really...
I didn't actually do the study because by the time I had spent three or four months
going through their data and talking with the
people in the department, I realized there
was no possible way.
He said, I mean, I tried to solve all these problems.
He said to me, just driving your meditators into the neighborhood will change the crime
rate.
I said, well, suppose I masquerade them as cleaners into an office building.
He said, do you think the people that are
crooks won't learn that they aren't actually
the cleaners?
Do you think they're not going to talk to the
cleaners because they don't do any research
before they break into the office building?
Oh, no, I hadn't thought of that.
He said, you can't introduce a variable
into a neighborhood without causing changes.
And so I would say this, there is no question
that if you get large numbers of people to
meditate that there is a massive change because
there is a change at the individual level,
the beingness of the people change.
And when the beingness of individuals change,
it's like the Quotidian choice thing we discussed.
When the beingness of the individuals change, the social consciousness changes.
And so I am sure, conceptually, that if you got
enough people in an area to meditate together,
that it would alter the social patterns of that area.
But trying to design a study that would really
withstand rigorous examination, that where
you controlled all the variables that could have an effect, I just found, I mean, maybe
with a huge amount of money you could do it,
but I, at the end of the day, having put almost
a year, by the time it was over, having put
almost a year into trying to design an experiment
to see whether this proposition worked, I
just had to give up because I simply couldn't
control all the variables.
And, of course, one of the first things to be suspicious of in any research is when an
organization does research for the purpose of promoting themselves.
Whether it's a commercial organization or a
religious organization, that is always immediately
suspect.
Yes.
If you look at, for instance, the therapeutic
intention, the healing research, Wayne Jonas,
the president of the Samueli Institute, did
all of that, and the lowest rating for quality
of research was religious research, which
basically started with a conclusion and then
designed an experiment to validate the conclusion.
You have to start with a hypothesis and test
the hypothesis, and maybe it works, maybe
it doesn't.
So it's very difficult to do that social level at that detail.
But I think it is quite clear, and again, we've
discussed Roger Nelson's Global Consciousness
Project, where you have large masses of people
who hold intention-focused awareness for a
moment about something, you cause a change in social structure.
And we have the power to change our personal
beingness and, in the change of our own personal
beingness, to change the world.
A good reason to encourage everybody to find a way to meditate that works for them.
Absolutely.
Stephen Schwartz, thank you so much for sharing this with me.
Glad to.
Very important conversation.
Thanks.
And thank you for being with us.
Thank you.
